# Icarus

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

For other uses, see [Icarus (disambiguation)](/wiki/Icarus_\(disambiguation\)
"Icarus \(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Gowy-icaro-
prado.jpg/250px-Gowy-icaro-prado.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gowy-icaro-prado.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gowy-icaro-prado.jpg "Enlarge")

[Jacob Peter Gowy](/wiki/Jacob_Peter_Gowy "Jacob Peter Gowy")'s _The Flight of
Icarus_.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Icarus_and_Daedalus.jpg/220px-
Icarus_and_Daedalus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Icarus_and_Daedalus.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Icarus_and_Daedalus.jpg "Enlarge")

Icarus and Daedalus ancient red relief plastic pottery beaker, Roman-Greece

In [Greek mythology](/wiki/Greek_mythology "Greek mythology"), **Icarus** (the
Latin spelling, conventionally adopted in English; [Ancient
Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language "Ancient Greek language"): Ἴκαρος,
_Íkaros_ , [Etruscan](/wiki/Etruscan_language "Etruscan language"):
_Vikare_[1]) is the son of the master craftsman [Daedalus](/wiki/Daedalus
"Daedalus"), the creator of the [Labyrinth](/wiki/Labyrinth "Labyrinth").
Icarus and his father attempt to escape from [Crete](/wiki/Crete "Crete") by
means of wings that his father constructed from feathers and wax. Icarus'
father warns him first of complacency and then of [hubris](/wiki/Hubris
"Hubris"), asking that he fly neither too low nor too high, so the sea's
dampness would not clog his wings or the sun's heat melt them. Icarus ignored
his father's instructions not to fly too close to the sun; when the wax in his
wings melted he tumbled out of the sky and fell into the sea where he drowned,
sparking the idiom _" don't fly too close to the sun"_.

This tragic theme of failure at the hands of hubris contains similarities to
that of [Phaëthon](/wiki/Phaethon "Phaethon").

## Contents

  * 1 The legend
  * 2 Classical literature
  * 3 Medieval and Renaissance literature
  * 4 Interpretation
  * 5 See also

## The legend[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Icarus&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: The legend")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Draper_Herbert_James_Mourning_for_Icarus.jpg/220px-
Draper_Herbert_James_Mourning_for_Icarus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Draper_Herbert_James_Mourning_for_Icarus.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Draper_Herbert_James_Mourning_for_Icarus.jpg "Enlarge")

_[The Lament for Icarus](/wiki/The_Lament_for_Icarus "The Lament for Icarus")_
by [H. J. Draper](/wiki/Herbert_James_Draper "Herbert James Draper")

Icarus' father [Daedalus](/wiki/Daedalus "Daedalus"), a very talented and
remarkable [Athenian](/wiki/Athens "Athens") craftsman, built the
[Labyrinth](/wiki/Cretan_Labyrinth "Cretan Labyrinth") for [King
Minos](/wiki/Minos "Minos") of Crete near his palace at
[Knossos](/wiki/Knossos "Knossos") to imprison the [Minotaur](/wiki/Minotaur
"Minotaur"), a half-man, half-bull monster born of his wife and the [Cretan
bull](/wiki/Cretan_bull "Cretan bull"). Minos imprisoned Daedalus himself in
the labyrinth because he gave Minos's daughter, [Ariadne](/wiki/Ariadne
"Ariadne"), a [clew](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/clew "wikt:clew")[2] (or
ball of string) in order to help [Theseus](/wiki/Theseus "Theseus"), the enemy
of Minos, to survive the Labyrinth and defeat the Minotaur.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Ikaria_and_Ikarus_graffiti_at_Evdilos%2C_Ikaria_island_-
_Greece.jpg/220px-Ikaria_and_Ikarus_graffiti_at_Evdilos%2C_Ikaria_island_-
_Greece.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ikaria_and_Ikarus_graffiti_at_Evdilos,_Ikaria_island_-
_Greece.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ikaria_and_Ikarus_graffiti_at_Evdilos,_Ikaria_island_-
_Greece.jpg "Enlarge")

Modern graffiti of Icaria island and falling Icarus just outside the village
of [Evdilos](/wiki/Evdilos "Evdilos") in [Icaria](/wiki/Icaria "Icaria") \-
[Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece")

Daedalus fashioned two pairs of wings out of wax and feathers for himself and
his son. Daedalus tried his wings first, but before trying to escape the
island, he warned his son not to fly too close to the sun, nor too close to
the sea, but to follow his path of flight. Overcome by the giddiness that
flying lent him, Icarus soared into the sky, but in the process he came too
close to the sun, which due to the [heat](/wiki/Heat "Heat") melted the wax.
Icarus kept flapping his wings but soon realized that he had no feathers left
and that he was only flapping his bare arms, and so Icarus fell into the sea
and drowned in the area which today bears his name, the [Icarian
Sea](/wiki/Icarian_Sea "Icarian Sea") near [Icaria](/wiki/Icaria "Icaria"), an
island southwest of [Samos](/wiki/Samos "Samos").[3][4][5]

Hellenistic writers give [euhemerising](/wiki/Euhemerism "Euhemerism")
variants in which the escape from Crete was actually by boat, provided by
Pasiphaë, for which Daedalus invented the first sails, to outstrip Minos'
pursuing galleys, and that Icarus fell overboard en route to Sicily and
drowned. [Heracles](/wiki/Heracles "Heracles") erected a tomb for him.[6][7]

## Classical literature[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Icarus&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Classical literature")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Fall_of_Icarus_Blondel_decoration_Louvre_INV2624.jpg/220px-
Fall_of_Icarus_Blondel_decoration_Louvre_INV2624.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fall_of_Icarus_Blondel_decoration_Louvre_INV2624.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Fall_of_Icarus_Blondel_decoration_Louvre_INV2624.jpg "Enlarge")

_The Sun, or the Fall of Icarus_ (1819) by [Merry-Joseph Blondel](/wiki/Merry-
Joseph_Blondel "Merry-Joseph Blondel"), in the Rotunda of Apollo at the
[Louvre](/wiki/Louvre "Louvre")

Icarus' flight was often alluded to by Greek poets in passing, but the story
was told briefly in Pseudo-Apollodorus.[8] In the [literature of ancient
Rome](/wiki/Latin_literature "Latin literature"), the myth was of interest to
[Augustan](/wiki/Augustan_literature_\(ancient_Rome\) "Augustan literature
\(ancient Rome\)") writers. [Hyginus](/wiki/Hyginus "Hyginus") narrates it in
_[Fabula](/wiki/Fabulae "Fabulae")_ 40, beginning with the bovine love affair
of [Pasiphaë](/wiki/Pasipha%C3%AB "Pasiphaë"), daughter of the Sun, resulting
in the birth of the [Minotaur](/wiki/Minotaur "Minotaur"). [Ovid](/wiki/Ovid
"Ovid") narrates the story of Icarus at some length in the
_[Metamorphoses](/wiki/Metamorphoses_\(poem\) "Metamorphoses \(poem\)")_
(viii.183–235), and refers to it elsewhere.[9]

## Medieval and Renaissance
literature[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Icarus&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Medieval and Renaissance literature")]

[![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-
Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg)| This
section **needs expansion**. You can help by [adding to
it](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Icarus&action=edit&section=).
_(January 2011)_  
---|---  
  
Ovid's treatment of the Icarus myth and its connection with that of
[Phaëthon](/wiki/Phaethon "Phaethon") influenced the mythological tradition in
[English literature](/wiki/English_literature "English literature")[10] as
received and interpreted by major writers such as [Chaucer](/wiki/Chaucer
"Chaucer"),[11] [Marlowe](/wiki/Christopher_Marlowe "Christopher
Marlowe"),[12] [Shakespeare](/wiki/Shakespeare "Shakespeare"),[13]
[Milton](/wiki/John_Milton "John Milton"),[14] and [Joyce](/wiki/James_Joyce
"James Joyce").[15]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Pieter_Bruegel_de_Oude_-
_De_val_van_Icarus.jpg/220px-Pieter_Bruegel_de_Oude_-
_De_val_van_Icarus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pieter_Bruegel_de_Oude_-
_De_val_van_Icarus.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pieter_Bruegel_de_Oude_-_De_val_van_Icarus.jpg "Enlarge")

[Bruegel](/wiki/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder "Pieter Bruegel the Elder")'s
_[Landscape with the Fall of Icarus](/wiki/Landscape_with_the_Fall_of_Icarus
"Landscape with the Fall of Icarus")_ (_ca._ 1558), famous for relegating the
fall to a scarcely noticed event in the background

In Renaissance [iconography](/wiki/Iconography "Iconography"), the
significance of Icarus depends on context: in the Orion Fountain at Messina,
he is one of many figures associated with water; but he is also shown on the
Bankruptcy Court of the Amsterdam Town Hall - where he
[symbolizes](/wiki/Symbol "Symbol") high-flying ambition.[16] The 16th-century
painting _[Landscape with the Fall of
Icarus](/wiki/Landscape_with_the_Fall_of_Icarus "Landscape with the Fall of
Icarus")_ , traditionally but perhaps erroneously attributed to [Pieter
Bruegel the Elder](/wiki/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder "Pieter Bruegel the Elder"),
was the inspiration for two of the 20th century's most notable
[ecphrastic](/wiki/Ecphrasis "Ecphrasis") English-language poems, "[Musée des
Beaux Arts](/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_des_Beaux_Arts_\(poem\) "Musée des Beaux Arts
\(poem\)")" by [W.H. Auden](/wiki/W.H._Auden "W.H. Auden") and "[Landscape
with the Fall of Icarus](/wiki/Landscape_with_the_Fall_of_Icarus_\(poem\)
"Landscape with the Fall of Icarus \(poem\)")" by [William Carlos
Williams](/wiki/William_Carlos_Williams "William Carlos Williams"). Other
English language poems referencing the Icarus myth are "To a Friend Whose Work
Has Come to Triumph" by [Anne Sexton](/wiki/Anne_Sexton "Anne Sexton"),
"Icarus Again" by Alan Devenish, "Mrs Icarus" by [Carol Ann
Duffy](/wiki/Carol_Ann_Duffy "Carol Ann Duffy"), "Failing and Flying" by [Jack
Gilbert](/wiki/Jack_Gilbert "Jack Gilbert"), and "Icarus Burning" and "Icarus
Redux" by Hiromi Yoshida.

## Interpretation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Icarus&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Interpretation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/%27The_Fall_of_Icarus%27%2C_17th_century%2C_Mus%C3%A9e_Antoine_Vivenel.JPG/220px-%27The_Fall_of_Icarus%27%2C_17th_century%2C_Mus%C3%A9e_Antoine_Vivenel.JPG)](/wiki/File:%27The_Fall_of_Icarus%27,_17th_century,_Mus%C3%A9e_Antoine_Vivenel.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:%27The_Fall_of_Icarus%27,_17th_century,_Mus%C3%A9e_Antoine_Vivenel.JPG
"Enlarge")

17th-century [relief](/wiki/Relief "Relief") with a [Cretan
labyrinth](/wiki/Labyrinth "Labyrinth") bottom right _([Musée Antoine
Vivenel](/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_Antoine_Vivenel "Musée Antoine Vivenel"))_

Literary interpretation has found in the myth the structure and consequence of
personal over-ambition.[17][18] An Icarus-related study of the
[Daedalus](/wiki/Daedalus "Daedalus") myth was published by the French
[hellenist](/wiki/Hellenic_studies "Hellenic studies") [Françoise Frontisi-
Ducroux](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fran%C3%A7oise_Frontisi-Ducroux
"fr:Françoise Frontisi-Ducroux").[19] In psychology there have been synthetic
studies of the _Icarus complex_ with respect to the alleged relationship
between fascination for fire, [enuresis](/wiki/Enuresis "Enuresis"), high
ambition, and ascensionism.[20] In the psychiatric mind features of disease
were perceived in the shape of the pendulous emotional ecstatic-_high_ and
depressive-_low_ of bipolar disorder. [Henry Murray](/wiki/Henry_Murray "Henry
Murray") having proposed the term _Icarus complex_ , apparently found symptoms
particularly in mania where a person is fond of heights, fascinated by both
fire and water, _[narcissistic](/wiki/Narcissism "Narcissism")_ and observed
with fantastical or _far-fetched imaginary_ cognition.[21][22]

## See also[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Icarus&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: See also")]

  * [Icarus imagery in contemporary music](/wiki/Icarus_imagery_in_contemporary_music "Icarus imagery in contemporary music")
  * [Kua Fu](/wiki/Kua_Fu "Kua Fu"), a Chinese myth about a giant who chased the sun and died while getting too close
  * [Bladud](/wiki/Bladud "Bladud"), a legendary king of the Britons, purported to have met his death when his constructed wings failed
  * [Etana](/wiki/Etana "Etana"), a sort of "Babylonian Icarus"[23]
  * [Sampati](/wiki/Sampati "Sampati"), an Indian myth about a bird which lost its wings while trying to save its younger brother from the sun
